An intern lost part of the RSA private key while emailing a secret message: 5900652990028381865524025833464296697199040359110084102776860105764123869156807284459384794806009334025737428091721826566598526698825570265743608605895223. Can you recover the plaintext using the leaked key bits?

The flag format is flag{...}
n=9304633289272977523571868025386579827276459238148122064398191901007465135720004846933233812185056671360415328539832073954691811757433819227613695769339717, e=1215608537291353913686284091383614635681927672481735856085162957887578966230254085196785709045616548159879481775262058854292677370341216402614891695224159, partial_p=15429763033262567849

---

## Challenge Technical Details
flag: flag{dakl6qmx}
cipher: RSA
ciphertext: 5900652990028381865524025833464296697199040359110084102776860105764123869156807284459384794806009334025737428091721826566598526698825570265743608605895223
vulnerability: partial key exposure
hint: A partial exposure of a prime number's bits can significantly weaken RSA security. Look into lattice-based techniques like Coppersmith's attack.
